summary: Educational video explaining the science and history of the telephone, from basic sound principles and Alexander Graham Bell's invention to modern telephone technology.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black screen, followed by a close-up of a vintage rotary telephone in a dimly lit room. The text "EFVA THE TELEPHONE" appears over the image, indicating the brand and subject of the video. The scene transitions to another text overlay, "GPO presented by THE GENERAL POST OFFICE," suggesting the involvement of the General Post Office in the production or sponsorship. The video then shifts to a young boy in a school uniform, sitting at a table with a lamp and a rotary telephone beside him. He is writing in a notebook, appearing focused and engaged in his task. The room is modestly furnished, with a window in the background, creating a quiet and studious atmosphere. The video captures the boy's concentration and the vintage setting, emphasizing the historical context of the telephone and the educational environment.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a distinct ringing sound, resembling a telephone or doorbell. This is followed by a male voice that starts explaining how telephones work by saying they need to "say a little about sound," with a formal and instructional speaking tone. Another instance of ringing is then heard.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a young boy in a school uniform, deeply engrossed in writing on a piece of paper at a table, with a vintage telephone and a decorative lamp nearby. The scene transitions to the boy standing by a window, holding a small object, possibly a piece of food, and then shifts to him outside, observing another person walking away in a garden. The boy is seen holding a small container with a stick, suggesting he might be preparing to light something. The video then shows a close-up of the boy's hands as he lights a match, followed by a scene where he is seen holding a small object near a window, possibly a candle or a small lantern. The video concludes with the boy standing by the window, looking outside, with the interior of the room visible in the background. The atmosphere throughout the video is one of quiet contemplation and curiosity, with the boy's actions suggesting a sense of purpose and focus.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male narrator explaining how "sound waves consist of small and rapid changes in air pressure," and mentions that "the number of changes per second is called the frequency of the sound." He describes the need for a diaphragm to reproduce sound, and refers to a boy making one with "a piece of tissue paper and a comb."  Then, a buzzing sound occurs, produced from the comb-and-paper diaphragm. The narrator then describes the use of two diaphragms connected by a string, and explains the transmission of sound between them.  Finally, a high-pitched buzzing sound occurs again.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a young boy in a school uniform standing in a garden, holding a camera and taking a photograph of another person in the distance. The scene transitions to a close-up of a man with a beard, looking to the side, followed by a close-up of his ear, emphasizing his facial features. The focus then shifts to a mechanical device, possibly a camera or projector, with wires and components visible, highlighting its intricate design. The video continues with a detailed view of the device's internal components, including a spool of wire and a rotating wheel, showcasing the complexity of the machinery. The final scene shows a person's hands adjusting the device, indicating a demonstration or examination of its functionality. The video maintains a black-and-white aesthetic throughout, emphasizing the historical or educational context of the content.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male narrator introducing Alexander Graham Bell's 1874 writing: "If I could make a current of electricity vary in intensity precisely as during the reproduction of sound, I should be able to transmit speech telegraphically." He continues in a neutral tone, describing a model of Bell's apparatus, explaining that it is connected to an identical instrument by a pair of wires and offers to explain how it works. He then describes the diaphragm, electromagnet, and permanent magnet core. The narrator notes that no battery was needed, but the current was weak and unsuitable for long distances.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a vintage rotary dial telephone placed on a flat surface, featuring a coiled cord and a handset resting on the base. The scene transitions to a detailed cross-sectional diagram of the telephone's internal components, highlighting the mechanical parts and wiring. Text appears on the screen, labeling various parts such as "TO LINE CIRCUIT & BATTERY," "CARBON GRANULES," and "DIAPHRAGM," providing an educational overview of the telephone's functionality. The video maintains a monochromatic color scheme throughout, emphasizing the technical and historical aspects of the telephone's design and operation.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a single male speaker, adopting an informative tone. He describes modern telephones and changes made over the years, focusing on the "diagram of a modern microphone" and its parts: a battery and wires carrying current, which connects to "the telephone wires", followed by a circuit filled with "granules of carbon". The narrator calls the instrument a "carbon granule microphone" and mentions the diaphragm, made of metal.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black and white illustration of a mechanical device, focusing on its internal components. The word "DIAPHRAGM" is prominently displayed, indicating the part of the device being highlighted. The illustration shows a cross-sectional view of the device, revealing its intricate internal structure, including a cylindrical component with a dotted line tracing its path. The background is plain, emphasizing the device's details. As the video progresses, the illustration zooms in on the cylindrical component, providing a closer look at its texture and the dotted line's path. The dotted line appears to represent the movement or flow within the device, with arrows indicating the direction of this movement. The video maintains a consistent black and white color scheme, focusing on the mechanical device's internal workings and the movement of its components.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker explaining the effect of a sound wave on a diaphragm. He describes how the wave pushes the diaphragm in, compresses granules, and alters the current flow. The male voice continues, speaking about how the sound waves are turned into a fluctuating current. He sounds instructional and is the only audible speaker.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a mechanical device featuring a cylindrical component and a gauge, with dotted lines indicating electrical connections. The gauge, labeled "SPEECH CURRENT," shows a needle pointing to the right, suggesting the measurement of electrical current related to speech. The scene transitions to a detailed view of a device's internal structure, highlighting a diaphragm and an electromagnet, with labels pointing to these components. The diaphragm is shown in motion, indicating its role in converting sound waves into electrical signals. The video maintains a monochromatic color scheme throughout, emphasizing the technical and educational nature of the content. The focus remains on the mechanical and electrical components, providing a clear and informative demonstration of the device's functionality.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker, sounding informative, describing the current as having two parts, the steady current from a battery and a fluctuating current due to sound waves, which he calls the speech current. He then describes how the current is turned back into sound waves in the receiver, so the speech can be heard. The speaker continues, mentioning a diaphragm attached to an iron bar that is pivoted and mounted close to the poles of an electromagnet, calling the bar a rocking armature, and mentions permanent magnetism in the electromagnet.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a cross-sectional diagram of a telephone receiver, highlighting its internal components such as the diaphragm and electro-magnet, with labels pointing to each part. The diagram is shown in black and white, with a simple, clean background. The camera zooms in on the electro-magnet, showing the magnetic field lines around it, and then zooms out to show the entire receiver again. The scene transitions to two boys sitting at a desk, each holding a telephone receiver to their ear, engaged in a conversation. They are dressed in school uniforms, with one boy wearing a blazer and the other a shirt and tie. The background is plain, with a spotlight effect illuminating the boys, creating a focused and intimate atmosphere. The video concludes with the boys continuing their conversation, emphasizing the connection between the internal mechanics of the telephone and its use in everyday communication.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male narrator, speaking in a clear, explanatory tone, describing the function of a modern telephone receiver, stating that, "the modern receiver is not unlike Bell's original, but it is very much more sensitive." He goes on to describe how speech current affects the receiver and reproduces the original sound, noting this is "what happens when you speak to your friend on the telephone." The narration concludes by pointing out that nothing has been said about how telephones are connected to each other.

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with two men in suits, one standing and the other seated, both engaged in a phone conversation in a dimly lit room with a plain, slightly worn wall. The standing man holds a phone receiver to his ear, while the seated man, also holding a receiver, appears to be listening intently. The scene transitions to a close-up of a coiled telephone cord connected to a wall-mounted phone, with a hand adjusting the cord. The focus then shifts to a battery labeled "BATTERY" being connected to the phone's wiring, with hands carefully attaching the wires. The men are then shown again, with the standing man leaning forward, seemingly in distress, while the seated man continues to hold the receiver. The video concludes with a close-up of the phone's dial, as a hand dials a number, indicating an attempt to make a call. The overall atmosphere is tense and focused, with the men's actions suggesting urgency or concern.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker, who in a neutral tone, instructs, "Let's look into this now" and presents a microphone. He explains that it needs direct current from a battery to work. The speaker notes that one might connect the microphone, battery, and receiver in series, so person A can speak to person B, but that such a system is wasteful. He concludes that the telephone system is connected differently because the battery has to do more work than is necessary.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with two boys in school uniforms standing in a room with a plain wall behind them. One boy is seated at a desk with a telephone and various objects, including a transformer, a battery, and a coil of wire. The other boy stands beside the desk, observing the items. The scene transitions to a close-up of the transformer, labeled "TRANSFORMER," with its specifications visible. The boys are then shown working together, connecting wires to the transformer and battery, with a label indicating "INPUT - low voltage." The focus shifts to a wider view of the setup, showing the entire circuit laid out on the desk, with the boys continuing to adjust the connections. The video concludes with a detailed view of the completed circuit, highlighting the arrangement of the transformer, battery, and coils, with the boys' hands still visible, indicating their ongoing involvement in the experiment. The atmosphere is educational, with a focus on demonstrating the principles of electricity and circuitry.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker with a formal, instructional tone. He describes using transformers to connect telephones, emphasizing their ability to pass fluctuating current while stopping steady current. He continues, explaining how to use a transformer to step up voltage and send messages over greater distances. The speaker then describes how a basic circuit can only speak in one direction, and how it would be possible to use another identical circuit to speak in both directions, but he notes that it is wasteful, and therefore one can rearrange the connections to do so. The speaker concludes that the microphone and receiver are now coupled together through the transformers at each end.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black and white shot of a table with various electronic components and wires laid out on it, suggesting a demonstration or experiment setup. The scene transitions to a close-up of a sign reading "TELEPHONE EXCHANGE," indicating the subject matter of the video. The next frames show a diagrammatic representation of a telephone exchange system, with two labeled points, "A" and "B," connected by lines representing telephone lines. The diagram includes a central "TELEPHONE EXCHANGE" label, emphasizing the role of the exchange in connecting the two points. The video concludes with a zoomed-in view of the diagram, highlighting the telephone handsets at points "A" and "B," illustrating the connection between the two ends through the telephone exchange. The overall atmosphere is educational, focusing on the technical aspects of telephone communication systems.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with one speaker, male, explaining the function of certain switches and telephone hooks which "break the circuit," followed by their explanation of how they need "bells" that are connected so that they can be rung, "even though the switches are open." He explains that the current to ring the bells comes from the telephone exchange, which has the equipment to connect telephones, and states that the clip shows the parts spread out but in reality are boxed together, except for the battery. He continues by saying, "we can now see what happens when a call is made."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black and white illustration of two old-fashioned rotary dial telephones connected by a line labeled "TELEPHONE EXCHANGE," indicating the central hub for telephone connections. The scene transitions to a young boy in a school uniform holding a telephone receiver, with an inset image of a telephone exchange switchboard in the background. The focus then shifts to a detailed diagram of a telephone exchange system, showing various components and connections, with the boy still visible in the inset. The narrative continues with a close-up of two women operating a switchboard, manipulating the numerous wires and plugs to connect calls. The scene then returns to a simplified diagram of the telephone exchange system, highlighting the connection between two phones labeled "A" and "B," with the boy and a girl in school uniforms holding receivers. The video progresses to a wider shot of a telephone exchange room, where multiple operators are seated at switchboards, diligently working. The final frames show a close-up of the switchboard's mechanical components, emphasizing the intricate network of wires and plugs that facilitate telephone connections. Throughout the video, the black and white aesthetic and the focus on the technical aspects of telephone exchanges provide a historical perspective on the evolution of communication technology.
events_list.audio_caption:
The audio clip starts with a male narrator describing the process of telephone communication, explaining the steps A must take to call B and the operator's role in connecting the call. There's a brief dialogue between two individuals, identified as a male named Eric and a female named Joe. Eric asks how she is, and she responds.
The narrator continues, discussing the energy transmitted through telephones. The dialogue concludes with Eric saying goodbye and Joe returning the farewell. The clip continues with the narrator discussing more telephones in a busy place. The narrator emphasizes the direct link is established between the caller and the called, and speaking about the capability of speaking to people around the world.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a man speaking into a vintage telephone receiver, his profile visible against a plain background. The scene transitions to a close-up of the telephone's mechanical components, highlighting the intricate details of the device. The video then shifts to a title screen displaying the text "produced by TECHNICAL AND SCIENTIFIC FILMS LTD. (in association with the Film Producers Guild) made in co-operation with THE NATIONAL COMMITTEE FOR AUDIO-VISUAL AIDS IN EDUCATION Adviser: Sydney Wood 1962." This is followed by another title screen with additional credits, including "Produced by Denis Ward B.Sc., Ph.D., Directed by David Cons B.Sc., Photographed by Charles K. French, Edited by Peter Heffron, Diagrams by Guild Animation, Ltd." The final title screen lists the distribution details, "Distribution THE EDUCATIONAL FOUNDATION FOR VISUAL AIDS 33, Queen Anne Street, London, W.1." The video maintains a monochromatic color scheme throughout, emphasizing the historical and educational nature of the content.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker, who speaks in a formal, informative tone, stating, "We can do so because of the fact that one diaphragm can be made to reproduce the fluctuations of another." The speech is followed by a loud, harsh, and gradually increasing buzzing sound.
